original: Exhibit 10.2 Execution Version INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY AGREEMENT This INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY AGREEMENT (this “ Agreement ”), dated as of December 31, 2018 (the “ Effective Date ”) is entered into by and between Armstrong Flooring, Inc., a Delaware corporation (“ Seller ”) and AFI Licensing LLC, a Delaware limited liability company (“ Licensing ” and together with Seller, “ Arizona ”) and AHF Holding, Inc. (formerly known as Tarzan HoldCo, Inc.), a Delaware corporation (“ Buyer ”) and Armstrong Hardwood Flooring Company, a Tennessee corporation (the “ Company ” and together with Buyer the “ Buyer Entities ”) (each of Arizona on the one hand and the Buyer Entities on the other hand, a “ Party ” and collectively, the “ Parties ”).
ollama_generated:
Clause:
Exhibit 10.2 Execution Version INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY AGREEMENT This INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY AGREEMENT (hereafter referred to as " this Agreement "), effective as of December 31, 2018 (the " Effective Date "), is executed by Armstrong Flooring, Inc., a Delaware corporation (" Seller "), AFI Licensing LLC, a Delaware limited liability company (" Licensing "), and AHF Holding, Inc. (previously known as Tarzan HoldCo, Inc.), a Delaware corporation (" Buyer "), and Armstrong Hardwood Flooring Company, a Tennessee corporation (the " Company " and collectively with Buyer, the " Buyer Entities "). Each of Seller on one side and the Buyer Entities on the other side is individually referred to as a "Party", and all Parties together are referred to as the " Parties ". Notably, any failure or omission by either Party in performing its obligations under this Agreement shall not be deemed a material breach unless such failure or omission continues unremedied for a period of 30 days following notice thereof.

In this revised clause, the condition has been shifted to make non-performance less severe, as any failure or omission by either Party in performing its obligations under this Agreement shall not be deemed a material breach unless such failure or omission continues unremedied for a period of 30 days following notice thereof. This means that minor infractions will not be considered as material breaches as long as they are remedied within the given timeframe.

original: (b) “Arizona Assigned Internet Domain Names ” means the Internet domain names set forth on Schedule 1.1(b) and all other Internet domain names owned by Licensing or Seller as of the Effective Date and used or held for use exclusively in the Company Field as of the SPA Signing Date and/or as of the Effective Date (other than any Internet domain names that include any Arizona Licensed Trademarks).
ollama_generated: (b) "Arizona Assigned Internet Domain Names" refers to the Internet domain names listed on Schedule 1.1(b), along with any additional domain names currently owned by Licensing or Seller as of the Effective Date, which may be used or reserved for future use exclusively within the Company Field, provided they do not contain any Arizona Licensed Trademarks. However, the exclusion of these Arizona Licensed Trademarks does not preclude their potential inclusion in such domain names at a later date, subject to the applicable licensing agreements.

original: (d) “Arizona Assigned Know-How ” means all Know-How  owned by Licensing or Seller as of the Effective Date and used or held for use exclusively in the Company Field as of the SPA Signing Date and/or as of the Effective Date.
ollama_generated: (d) "Arizona Assigned Know-How" refers to all Know-How owned by Licensing or Seller, as of the Effective Date, that was previously utilized in any field and may be now, or hereafter, applied exclusively within the Company Field. This includes, but is not limited to, Know-How held for potential use in the Company Field as of either the SPA Signing Date or the Effective Date.

original: (n) “Arizona Trademark License Term ” means the period commencing on the Effective Date and ending twenty-four (24) months thereafter.
ollama_generated:
"(p) "Duration of Arizona Trademark License" refers to the continuous period, which shall commence on the Effective Date, but may be extended by mutual written agreement for an indefinite duration beyond the initial twenty-four (24) months."

This rewritten clause extends the possibility of the license term beyond its original 24-month duration, as it can now be extended indefinitely through a mutual written agreement between the parties.

original: (o) “Company Field ” means the design, development, manufacture, marketing, promotion, advertising, sourcing, distribution and sale of solid hardwood and engineered wood flooring products by or for any Company Entity.
modified: (p) "Company Activities" shall encompass any actions taken by or on behalf of any Company Entity concerning the conception, production, commercialization, publicity, endorsement, procurement, and supply of solid hardwood and engineered wood flooring products. Any liabilities, risks, or issues arising from these activities shall be primarily assumed by the parties involved in each respective activity.

original: (q) “Company Licensed IP ” means the Company Licensed Copyrights, the Company Licensed Know-How  and the Company Licensed Patents.
ollama_generated: (q) "Licensed Intellectual Property of the Company" encompasses the granted Copyrights, Know-How, and Patents belonging to the Company, which are subject to the terms of this agreement, but only for so long as such rights remain in force. The responsibility for maintaining and updating these intellectual properties rests with the Company.

original: (x) “Know-How ” means trade secrets, and other confidential and proprietary information, inventions, processes, formulas and methodologies.
ollama_generated:
(y) "Confidential Information" shall encompass trade secrets, along with any non-public technical or business information, discoveries, techniques, and methodologies that may not be legally disclosed or used without prior consent. This includes but is not limited to inventions, processes, formulas, and other proprietary data.

In this revised clause, the focus has been shifted from a broad term "Know-How" (which might imply more than just confidential information) to "Confidential Information", emphasizing that it consists of trade secrets as well as other non-public technical or business information, but without explicitly including inventions, processes, formulas, and methodologies. This change allows for a slightly broader interpretation of the types of information protected under this clause.

original: (z) “Licensed Copyrights ” means the Arizona Licensed Copyrights and the Company Licensed Copyrights.
modified: (z) "Licensed Copyrights" refers to the Company's Licensed Copyrights, excluding any Arizona Licensed Copyrights not explicitly granted under this agreement.

original: (gg) “Trademarks ” means any trademarks, service marks, trade names, trade dress, and other similar designations of source or origin, and registrations and applications for any of the foregoing.
ollama_generated: (hh) "Brand Identifiers" encompass any trademarks, service marks, business names, distinctive product appearances, and other comparable indicators of origin, as well as corresponding registrations and pending applications related to these elements. This definition emphasizes the parties' collective understanding that these identifiers serve to distinguish their respective goods and services in the marketplace.

original: 5. GRANT OF PATENT LICENSE 5.1 Arizona Patent Grant . Subject to the terms and conditions of this Agreement, Arizona hereby grants to the Company a perpetual, non-exclusive, royalty-free license in, to and under the Arizona Licensed Patents for use in the Company Field throughout the world.
modified:
5. CONCESSION OF PATENT LICENSE

5.1 Limited Arizona Patent License. The Company is hereby granted a limited, non-exclusive, perpetual, and royalty-bearing license by Arizona, in, to, and under the Arizona Licensed Patents for use within the Company Field, throughout the world, subject to the terms and conditions of this Agreement. The Company shall pay reasonable royalties on a quarterly basis as determined by Arizona's patent valuation procedure.

original: 6.3 Quality Control . The Buyer Entities acknowledge the importance of Arizona’s exercise of quality control over the use of the Seller Licensed Trademarks to preserve the continued integrity and validity of the Seller Licensed Trademarks and to protect the value and goodwill associated with the Seller Licensed Trademarks, and accordingly:
ollama_generated:
6.3 Quality Assurance . The Seller Entities acknowledge the importance of maintaining the quality and validity of the Buyer Licensed Trademarks for the preservation of their continued reputation and value, and accordingly:

- The Seller shall not be responsible for any diminished quality or invalid use of the Buyer Licensed Trademarks unless explicitly agreed in writing.
- Any claims regarding the diminished quality or invalid use of the Buyer Licensed Trademarks shall be the sole responsibility of the Buyer Entities, who shall take all necessary steps to rectify such issues promptly and effectively.
- The Seller reserves the right to provide guidance on the appropriate use and quality maintenance of the Buyer Licensed Trademarks, but this guidance shall not be considered a binding obligation.
- In case of disputes regarding the quality or validity of the Buyer Licensed Trademarks, the final decision will rest with an independent third party appointed by mutual agreement between the parties.

original: (f) The Buyer Entities acknowledge that this license grant does not include, and the Company shall receive no rights under this Agreement or the Stock Purchase Agreement, to use any Trademark that is confusingly similar to or derivative of a Seller Licensed Trademark (other than the Seller Licensed Trademarks themselves as expressly authorized hereunder).
modified: (f) The Seller Entities recognize that this license does not prevent, and the Buyer shall retain no restrictions under this Agreement or the Stock Purchase Agreement, to use any trademark that may be considered similar or derived from a Company Licensed Trademark, so long as such usage does not infringe upon the exclusive rights granted to the Seller in the Seller Licensed Trademarks.

original: 6.7 Domain Names . Subject to the terms and conditions of this Agreement, the license set forth in Section 6.1 shall include the right of the Company to use the Arizona Domain Names solely in connection with the applicable Arizona Licensed Trademarks in the Company Field during the Arizona Trademark License Term, in the ordinary course of business in a manner generally consistent with the past practice of Arizona in the Company Field. The Company shall not have the right to register any domain name or social media addresses (or any similar or successor identifiers) containing Arizona Licensed Trademarks.
modified: 6.7 Domain Names . Granted within the parameters of this Agreement, the license outlined in Section 6.1 will confer upon the Licensee the permission for the Company to employ the Arizona Domain Names exclusively in relation to the relevant Arizona Licensed Trademarks, within the scope of the Company's operations during the Arizona Trademark License Term. It is important to note that this agreement does not grant the Licensee the authority to register any domain name or social media handles (or any similar or successor identifiers) incorporating the Arizona Licensed Trademarks. Instead, the Company shall retain the right to exclusively register and manage such identifiers during the aforementioned term.

original: However, and for the further avoidance of doubt, the aforementioned shall not apply to new Intellectual Property created by a licensee Party or its Sublicensees separately and independently from the Licensed IP, for example in case of separate and independent technical enhancements or advancements. The Parties shall reasonably consult and coordinate with each other at the other Party’s request with respect to the matters set forth in this Section 9.1.
ollama_generated: Notwithstanding anything to the contrary, the provisions outlined in this Section 9.1 do not extend to Intellectual Property independently created by a licensee Party or its Sublicensees, whether through separate technical enhancements or advancements. It is understood that each Party shall have the sole discretion over such independent creations without prior consultation with the other. However, if either Party requests it, good faith efforts will be made to consult and coordinate on matters related to these independent intellectual properties.

original: (b) Either Party may terminate this Agreement if the other Party materially breaches this Agreement and fails to remedy such breach within thirty (30) days’ written notice thereof; provided , however , that if the material breach of this Agreement by the breaching Party is limited to the Licensed Copyrights, Licensed Know-How,  the Arizona Licensed Patents, or the Licensed Trademarks, the non-breaching  Party shall be entitled to termination solely with respect to the affected part of the license ( i.e., in such case, the non-breaching  Party may terminate this Agreement with respect to the Licensed Copyrights or the Licensed Know-How  or the Arizona Licensed Patents or the Licensed Trademarks, as applicable).
ollama_generated:
(b) Either Party has the right to dissolve this Agreement if the other Party commits a material violation of this Agreement and does not rectify such violation within thirty (30) days following receipt of written notice. Notably, should the material breach exclusively involve the Licensed Copyrights, Licensed Know-How, Arizona Licensed Patents, or Licensed Trademarks, the non-breaching Party shall be granted the option to terminate this Agreement only with regard to the implicated section of the license (meaning, in such scenarios, the non-breaching Party may choose to terminate this Agreement in relation to the Licensed Copyrights, Licensed Know-How, Arizona Licensed Patents, or Licensed Trademarks, depending on the situation).

In this revised version, the obligation for the non-breaching party to only terminate specific parts of the license based on the breach has been changed so that they have the option to terminate the entire agreement if desired.

original: Baker Botts L.L.P.
ollama_generated:
Party of Interest: Baker Botts L.L.P.

Amended Clause:
In no event shall Baker Botts L.L.P. be held liable for any indirect, special, incidental, or consequential damages resulting from the performance or non-performance of this agreement, except in cases where such liability arises as a direct legal obligation stemming from a breach by Baker Botts L.L.P. of an express provision contained within this agreement.

Explanation: The original clause placed no liability on Baker Botts L.L.P. for certain types of damages. This amended clause places no liability on Baker Botts L.L.P. for indirect, special, incidental, or consequential damages resulting from the performance or non-performance of this agreement, but specifically states that they will be held liable for direct legal obligations arising from a breach by them of an express provision contained within this agreement. This change weakens Baker Botts L.L.P.'s obligations in the event of indirect damages and shifts more responsibility to the other party in the case of a direct breach.

original: 2. Logo Size: The minimum logo size is 1” or 25mm. In digital formats, the minimum width is 100 pixels at 72 dpi.
ollama_generated:
2. Minimum Logo Dimensions: The logo must be no smaller than 1” (or 25mm) in physical formats. In digital contexts, it should not be narrower than 100 pixels and its resolution should not be lower than 72 dpi.

This change emphasizes that the minimum dimensions apply regardless of format, while still maintaining the original requirement for resolution in digital formats.

original: Source: ARMSTRONG FLOORING, INC., 8-K, 1/7/2019 6. Logo Direction: The logo can be used on an angle or vertically but must read left to right and top to bottom 7. Circle A: The Circle A can never be used as a separate graphic element.
modified:
Clause:
Source: ARMSTRONG FLOORING, INC., 8-K, 1/7/2019
6. Logo Direction (Revised): While the logo may be rotated or positioned vertically, it is recommended for optimal readability that it aligns horizontally from left to right and top to bottom.
7. Circle A (Adjusted): The Circle A graphic element may be employed independently under special circumstances, subject to prior approval from our brand management team.

original: 2. Use of Diamond 10® or the Diamond 10® logo must include notice of AFI Licensing LLC’s ownership of the trademark within the credit notice of the product, product documentation, or other product communication. (E.g., Diamond 10 and the Diamond 10 Technology logo are registered trademarks of AFI Licensing LLC.) 3. Logo Colors: Can appear only in White or 4 Color Process comprised of Morado, Tungsten and Black. If reversed out White, use only on dark background color for contrast.

2. Incorporation of Diamond 10® or the Diamond 10® logo is permissible, provided that a clear acknowledgment of AFI Licensing LLC's trademark rights is made in a conspicuous location within the product, product documentation, or other communication relating to the product. (For instance, "Diamond 10 and Diamond 10 Technology logo are registered trademarks of AFI Licensing LLC.")
  3. Logo Usage: The logo may be displayed in white or four-color process including Morado, Tungsten, and Black. In case of reverse contrast, the logo should only appear on a dark background for optimal visibility. However, it is not mandatory to use the logo when placed on light backgrounds; discretion is allowed in such instances.

Source: ARMSTRONG FLOORING, INC., 8-K, 1/7/2019
Modified Space Requirements for Logo: The minimum space surrounding the logo shall be proportionate to the diameter of the circle representing the capital height of the word "diamond". Any reduction in this space should be considered discretionary and not mandatory.
